column11: Bankfull shear stress fits substrate/banks, indicating stable capacity.
column13: Bankfull width-depth vs regional curves
column20: Observation: Bankfull width and depth closely match regional curves for the drainage area and slope. Bars and banks remain stable through ~1-2 yr flows. Criteria: Near regional curve; stable
column23: Observation: Slightly oversized or undersized relative to curves. Isolated bank slumps after moderate events. Criteria: Mild departure; occasional instability
column29: Observation: Noticeable mismatch to curves. Frequent bar growth or cutbank retreat after moderate events. Criteria: Significant departure; frequent instability
column32: Observation: Highly out of family. Repeated blowouts, chute formation, or bank failures with moderate floods. Criteria: Severe departure; chronic instability

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Peak flows reshape channel without chronic instability, redistribute wood and sediment, reset habitats, and supply nutrients to floodplains.
column11: Bankfull shear stress fits substrate/banks, indicating stable capacity.
column13: Manning's tau at Qbf (HEC-RAS/Excel)
column20: Observation: Velocity and shear match what the bed can resist. Only small bar tweaks or thin new deposits. Criteria: Near threshold; stable
column23: Observation: Small scour spots or minor deposition in a few places. Criteria: Slight mismatch; occasional instability
column29: Observation: Velocity and shear noticeably too high or too low. Bars grow, shift, or scour around structures after moderate flows. Criteria: Significant mismatch; frequent instability
column32: Observation: Widespread bank retreat, channel shifts, or large sediment deposits after moderate flows. Criteria: Extreme mismatch; chronic instability

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Frequent overbank flows reduce flood peaks, support riparian vegetation, create off-channel refugia, and extend nutrient processing time.
column11: Stable, not heavily dredged/incised, allowing normal overbank flows/meanders unless dredging is historical.
column13: Identify incision, dredging, levees, and spoil banks from imagery and confirm in the field or with historical sources where feasible.
column14: NAIP imagery and historical aerials/topos; National Levee Database (NLD) and FEMA floodplain layers (where available).
column20: Observation: No levees or spoil banks. Sinuous planform. No signs of dredging. Criteria: Stable channel. Not incised or dredged. Frequent floodplain access.
column23: Observation: Short straightened segment and intermittent spoil berm on one bank. Criteria: Slight channelization or partial dredging.
column29: Observation: Reach is incised by about 1-2 m with continuous spoil banks on one or both banks. Criteria: Heavily modified or incised with limited floodplain access.
column32: Observation: Recently dredged trapezoidal channel with levees along both banks. Criteria: Deeply dredged or fully channelized. No functional floodplain.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Frequent overbank flows reduce flood peaks, support riparian vegetation, create off-channel refugia, and extend nutrient processing time.
column11: Channel is not deeply incised; moderate floods access a broad floodplain, matching reference conditions.
column13: ER = floodplain width / bankfull depth
column20: Observation: LiDAR cross-sections show flood-prone width more than 2.2 times bankfull width. Criteria: ER > 2.2.
column23: Observation: Representative cross-section yields ER ~ 1.7. Criteria: ER ~1.4-2.2.
column29: Observation: Three cross-sections yield ER ~ 1.2. Criteria: ER < 1.4.
column32: Observation: Channel is walled or deeply incised with little widening at flood-prone elevation. Criteria: ER near 1.0 and confinement by levees or walls.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Frequent overbank flows reduce flood peaks, support riparian vegetation, create off-channel refugia, and extend nutrient processing time.
column11: Floodplain/off-channel features stay diverse/connected at moderate floods, reflecting minimal loss.
column13: Delineate side channels, oxbows, and wetlands and assess connectivity during moderate floods using field checks and available mapping.
column14: USFWS National Wetlands Inventory (NWI); NAIP imagery; USGS 3DEP DEM/hillshade; NHDPlus HR flowlines/waterbodies.
column20: Observation: Multiple active side channels, backwaters, and oxbows exchange flow during moderate floods. Field photos confirm inundation paths. Criteria: Several off-channel features connected at ~1-2 year stage; pattern resembles historical complexity.
column23: Observation: Some side channels remain but several are truncated by berms or levees. Connectivity occurs only in parts of the reach. Criteria: Partial complexity. Some features are disconnected at moderate floods.
column29: Observation: Only a small backwater remains. Most historic features are isolated or filled. Criteria: Most side channels lost or isolated. Minimal diversity of floodplain features.
column32: Observation: Both banks are leveed or the reach is straightened and dredged. No off-channel areas remain despite historical evidence. Criteria: Drastically simplified or leveed. No functional off-channel areas.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Frequent overbank flows reduce flood peaks, support riparian vegetation, create off-channel refugia, and extend nutrient processing time.
column11: 1-2 yr floods routinely access the floodplain, matching reference inundation patterns.
column13: Map bankfull inundation extent using a DEM and bankfull flow estimate and compare to mapped floodplain layers as a proxy for moderate-flood access.
column14: HEC-RAS 2D with USGS 3DEP DEM; bankfull flow estimate; FEMA floodplain layers (where available).
column20: Observation: HEC-RAS 2D shows the floodplain and backwaters inundate at ~Q2 with 0.3-0.6 m depths. Criteria: 1-2 year floods inundate side and backwaters.
column23: Observation: Inundation begins near ~Q3-Q5 with patchy coverage. Criteria: 3-5 year floods required for broad access.
column29: Observation: Little inundation until ~Q10. Backwaters remain dry in moderate events. Criteria: ~10 year event needed for access.
column32: Observation: No inundation until very large floods because of levees and incision. Criteria: Only extreme events produce inundation.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Surface water-groundwater exchange moderates temperature, transforms nutrients, supplies oxygen, and supports aquatic life.
column11: Substrate has coarse particles with minimal fines, enabling interstitial flow per local references.
column13: Perform a pebble count to estimate percent gravel and cobble versus fines and note evidence of embedding.
column14: Field pebble count; USGS or state surficial geology; high-resolution imagery for bar texture classes (where available).
column20: Observation: Pebble count shows clean gravel-cobble with open interstices. Criteria: Fines < 25%. Low embeddedness.
column23: Observation: Some fine matrix visible between gravels. Criteria: Fines 25-50%. Moderate embeddedness.
column29: Observation: Gravels largely buried by sand/silt. Criteria: Fines 50-75%. High embeddedness.
column32: Observation: Bed surface mostly sand, silt, or consolidated fines. Criteria: Fines >75%. Very high embeddedness.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Surface water-groundwater exchange moderates temperature, transforms nutrients, supplies oxygen, and supports aquatic life.
column11: Diverse bedforms enhance surface-subsurface exchange, matching reference morphology.
column13: Count riffle-pool or other bedform features per 100 m using imagery and a field check.
column14: High-resolution imagery and LiDAR hillshade (where available); longitudinal profile in GIS; field confirmation.
column20: Observation: Alternating riffle-pool sequence. Distinct head drops at riffles. Patchy dunes in sand-bed reaches. Criteria: Well-developed bedforms with obvious upwelling and downwelling zones.
column23: Observation: Some riffles and shallow pools but long uniform runs between. Criteria: Bedform variety present but partially uniform.
column29: Observation: Mostly long runs. Few weak riffles. Criteria: Mostly uniform habitat with limited exchange features.
column32: Observation: Featureless, planar bed with silt cover. Criteria: Bed lacks form. Exchange likely negligible.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Surface water-groundwater exchange moderates temperature, transforms nutrients, supplies oxygen, and supports aquatic life.
column11: Floodplain soils allow hyporheic/groundwater exchange, consistent with local reference.
column13: Assess soil texture and permeability in the floodplain using a hand texture test or auger. Use soils GIS as a desktop proxy where field access is limited.
column14: Field soil texture/permeability check; SSURGO or gSSURGO soils (HSG, Ksat, texture); Web Soil Survey; FEMA floodplain layers (where available).
column20: Observation: Hand-textured sands and sandy loams in frequently inundated swales. Groundwater mounding observed after floods. Criteria: Predominantly permeable floodplain soils supporting subsurface flow.
column23: Observation: Mixed sand over clay. Localized perched layers. Criteria: Partially permeable. Some clogging layers.
column29: Observation: Clayey overbank deposits or shallow bedrock exposed. Criteria: Mostly fine or shallow bedrock that limits infiltration.
column32: Observation: Spoil berms or compacted fill along banks. Criteria: Heavily compacted or lined. Minimal subsurface exchange.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Surface water-groundwater exchange moderates temperature, transforms nutrients, supplies oxygen, and supports aquatic life.
column11: Springs/seeps/subsurface flow show active hyporheic exchange, matching local reference.
column13: Tally active upwelling spots
column20: Observation: Multiple small upwelling boils at pool tails. Cold seeps along margins during summer. Criteria: Clear, frequent indicators of sub-surface flow.
column23: Observation: One or two seeps noted. Weak infiltration on riffle crests. Criteria: Occasional indicators.
column29: Observation: Questionable features. Staining but no active upwelling observed. Criteria: Rare or uncertain indicators.
column32: Observation: No seeps or infiltration zones observed at baseflow or falling limb. Criteria: No evidence. Bed appears sealed or compacted.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Long-term changes in channel size and slope maintain dynamic equilibrium and diverse habitats while interacting with the floodplain.
column11: Channel is stable/recovered (Stage I/VI or 0,1,6,8), not actively degrading, unless partial evolution is normal.
column13: Cluer-Thorne stage classification
column20: Observation: Low, vegetated banks. Frequent overbanking near bankfull. No fresh downcutting. Criteria: Schumm Stage I or VI. Cluer & Thorne stages 0-1 or 6-8.
column23: Observation: Point bars rebuilding. Patchy inset benches forming. Short raw segments remain. Criteria: Schumm Stage V or mid-range in Cluer & Thorne.
column29: Observation: Fresh slumps common. Bed appears lowered relative to floodplain. Criteria: Schumm Stage III-IV.
column32: Observation: Deeply entrenched cross-section with tall raw banks. Active knickpoint present. Criteria: Schumm Stage II or destructive phases.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Long-term changes in channel size and slope maintain dynamic equilibrium and diverse habitats while interacting with the floodplain.
column11: No active headcuts or fully stabilized ones; no ongoing incision or bank widening.
column13: GPS and photo headcut height/advance
column20: Observation: No headcuts mapped in imagery or field. Old steps fully vegetated. Criteria: No active headcuts.
column23: Observation: One small local knickpoint at a tributary junction with little change between dates. Criteria: Localized feature with limited progression.
column29: Observation: Headcut with fresh plunge pool and exposed strata observed in two locations. Upstream migration evident between image years. Criteria: One to two moderate, actively migrating headcuts.
column32: Observation: Several large headcuts marching upstream across the reach with widespread bank failures above cuts. Criteria: Multiple or large active headcuts with rapid advance.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Long-term changes in channel size and slope maintain dynamic equilibrium and diverse habitats while interacting with the floodplain.
column11: Channel shows vegetated benches/floodplain formation, indicating recovery from incision/widening.
column13: Presence of vegetated benches/inset floodplain
column20: Observation: Continuous inset benches on both banks with established woody and herbaceous cover. Criteria: Broad, established vegetated benches or inset floodplains.
column23: Observation: Patchy vegetated bars and short bench segments. Vegetation is establishing. Criteria: Noticeable but incomplete bench and bar formation.
column29: Observation: Narrow, mostly bare bars. Few inset surfaces. Fresh erosion visible. Criteria: Sparse new floodplain surfaces and limited vegetation.
column32: Observation: No benches or inset floodplains. Vertical raw banks dominate. Criteria: No meaningful signs of recovery.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Long-term changes in channel size and slope maintain dynamic equilibrium and diverse habitats while interacting with the floodplain.
column11: Bank erosion/migration rates match natural reference; no excessive widening unless historically typical.
column13: Map active channel edges across years and compute width change using imagery and field indicators where feasible.
column14: NAIP or Google Earth historical imagery; RivWidthCloud or RivMAP (where available).
column20: Observation: Digitized edges show minor width change over a decade. Bars and banks behave like nearby reference reaches. Criteria: Near-reference lateral change.
column23: Observation: Mild net widening over 10 years with occasional raw banks and quick revegetation. Criteria: Slightly above reference change.
column29: Observation: Width increased well beyond reference. Frequent mass failures or pronounced confinement in places. Criteria: Significantly above or below reference with instability or constraints.
column32: Observation: Rapid over-widening after storms, or planform fully locked by hardening that suppresses natural change. Criteria: Highly accelerated or heavily suppressed outside stable norms.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change. Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
column11: Integrates bank geometry, rooting, surface protection, raw or failing banks, and hardening to summarize erosion risk and sediment delivery.
column13: Score BEHI metrics (bank height ratio, rooting depth/density, angle, protection); map raw/slumping/undercut sections and percent eroding bank length; classify protection types; support with imagery.
column20: Observation: Well-vegetated banks with low BEHI; few raw spots. Criteria: Only small, scattered eroding segments that recover quickly.
column23: Observation: Patchy vegetation and moderate BEHI; some raw or slumping sections. Criteria: Noticeable but limited eroding length.
column29: Observation: Many long raw sections; high BEHI; widespread erosion. Criteria: Large portions of bankline actively eroding or failing.
column32: Observation: Very high BEHI; >50% bankline eroding or failing; failing armor. Criteria: Extensive bare/slumped banks and deteriorating protection.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change. Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
column11: Compares meander migration rates and cutoff frequency to reference behavior; excessive migration or avulsions indicate instability.
column13: Compare historic aerials; digitize centerlines or bank edges when possible to measure lateral movement; otherwise use qualitative evidence of bend migration, cutoffs, and oxbows; compare to reference reaches.
column20: Observation: Slow, natural bend movement matches nearby reference. Criteria: Cutoffs rare; migration rate near reference.
column23: Observation: Slightly faster or constrained migration; occasional cutoffs. Criteria: Minor departure from reference behavior.
column29: Observation: Noticeably accelerated migration or several cutoffs in recent decades. Criteria: Migration about 2-3x reference or chute cutoffs common.
column32: Observation: Very rapid migration, avulsions, or channel jumps. Criteria: Frequent or large cutoffs; path strongly out of character for setting.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change. Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
column11: Assesses whether planform and number of active threads match the natural setting, considering straightening, braiding, and side-channel connectivity.
column13: Use recent imagery and field checks to compare current planform to historic; note straightened segments, thread count, bar/island patterns, and whether side channels connect at about bankfull.
column20: Observation: Planform natural for valley; expected thread count; side channels connected. Criteria: Little/no straightening; side channels carry water near bankfull; pattern matches reference.
column23: Observation: Some simplified segments but generally natural. Criteria: Minor realignment or slight thread-count departure; limited side-channel connectivity.
column29: Observation: Clear realignment or planform departure; side channels mostly inactive. Criteria: Long straight segments or mismatched thread count; side channels disconnected except larger floods.
column32: Observation: Heavily straightened or artificial planform. Criteria: Strongly out of character; side channels absent or blocked by berms/spoil/levees.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change. Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
column11: Ratio of channel length to valley length; higher sinuosity indicates greater curvature and habitat variety.
column13: Compute channel centerline length divided by valley length in GIS.
column14: Rosgen (2006).
column20: Observation: Meanders occupy valley floor; bars well developed. Criteria: Sinuosity ~1.2-1.5 or matches local reference.
column23: Observation: Gentle bends with long straight runs. Criteria: Sinuosity ~1.1-1.2.
column29: Observation: Mostly straight with infrequent bends. Criteria: Sinuosity ~1.05-1.1.
column32: Observation: Channelized or straight through a meander belt. Criteria: Sinuosity <1.05 where meanders are expected.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Balanced sediment supply and transport preserves bed elevations, substrate sizes, spawning/benthic habitats, and supports riparian succession.
column11: Bed is stable, with no active incision disconnecting floodplain unless minor incision is normal.
column13: Cross-section repeat survey or visual headcut
column20: Observation: Low banks with inset benches. No active headcuts observed. Criteria: ER > 2.2. No active headcuts (Rosgen 1996, 2006).
column23: Observation: Localized bed lowering. One small headcut with vegetation establishing. Criteria: ER ~1.4-2.2. Limited headcut activity (Rosgen 1996, 2006).
column29: Observation: High banks and lowered bed. One to two moderate headcuts migrating. Criteria: ER < 1.4. Observable upstream migration of headcuts (Simon & Rinaldi 2006).
column32: Observation: Multiple large active headcuts. Floodplain largely disconnected. Criteria: ER < 1.4 reach-wide. Widespread incision (Schumm et al., 1984; Rosgen 2006).

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Balanced sediment supply and transport preserves bed elevations, substrate sizes, spawning/benthic habitats, and supports riparian succession.
column11: Fine input aligns with transport, unless higher turbidity/fines are historically normal (e.g., blackwater).
column13: Review available turbidity or TSS data and visually assess bed fines. Where data are absent, infer risk from land use and soils.
column14: EPA Water Quality Portal (turbidity/TSS); USGS NWIS (where available); NLCD land cover; SSURGO K-factor (erodibility).
column20: Observation: Gravel-cobble riffles with open voids. Thin or absent silt film. Criteria: Embeddedness < 25% (Class 1) (Sylte & Fischenich 2002).
column23: Observation: Some fines in pools and along margins. Riffles mostly clean. Criteria: Embeddedness 25-50% (Class 2) (Sylte & Fischenich 2002).
column29: Observation: Riffles partly blanketed in silt after storms. Fines persist for weeks. Criteria: Embeddedness 50-75% (Class 3) (Sylte & Fischenich 2002).
column32: Observation: Substrate largely buried in fines. Chronic turbidity even at low flow. Criteria: Embeddedness > 75% (Class 4) (Sylte & Fischenich 2002).

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Balanced sediment supply and transport preserves bed elevations, substrate sizes, spawning/benthic habitats, and supports riparian succession.
column11: Deposition matches natural form, no severe bar formation beyond typical references.
column13: Delineate bar types (point, mid-channel, lateral) and compare to expected morphology for the channel type.
column14: NAIP or orthophotos; LiDAR bare-earth DEM (where available).
column20: Observation: Point bars present on bends. No persistent mid-channel bars. Criteria: Bar types and locations match expected reference for a single-thread meandering channel (Leopold et al., 1964).
column23: Observation: Small lateral bars and occasional temporary islands. Criteria: Minor departures from reference pattern.
column29: Observation: Multiple mid-channel bars that persist year to year and split flow. Criteria: Pattern suggests imbalance in supply vs transport for expected channel type (Bridge 2003).
column32: Observation: Reach clogged with large deposits that force multi-threading where not natural. Criteria: Widespread bar growth inconsistent with reference condition.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Balanced sediment supply and transport preserves bed elevations, substrate sizes, spawning/benthic habitats, and supports riparian succession.
column11: Flow/slope balance incoming sediment, avoiding major bars or deep scour, unless imbalance is historically normal.
column13: Screen stream power using discharge and slope and compare with observed bars or scour. Detailed transport modeling is beyond screening.
column14: USGS StreamStats flow statistics (where available); NHDPlus HR slope; NAIP imagery for bar validation.
column20: Observation: Bars form on inner bends and migrate gradually. Pools maintained. Criteria: Bankfull Shields stress ~0.03-0.06 and consistent with D50. Morphology shows balanced scour/fill (Buffington & Montgomery 1997).
column23: Observation: Modest bar growth in low-energy sections. Some narrowing. Criteria: Shields slightly below critical range. Minor deposition.
column29: Observation: Large new bars in straight sections. Pools infilling. Criteria: Shields well below critical range. Under-capacity relative to supply.
column32: Observation: Deep scour and exposed armor. Few bars remain. Criteria: Shields well above critical range. Persistent over-capacity (Knighton 1998).

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Supports aquatic habitats through streambed material and bedform dynamics. Enhances habitat complexity and streambank stability.
column11: Presence and clarity of expected bedform sequence (riffle-run-pool or step-pool) indicate organized transport and habitat variety.
column13: Count presence of riffle, run, pool, or step-pool units and note whether sequences are intact.
column14: Field habitat mapping; high-resolution imagery; planform metrics (for example sinuosity) as supporting context.
column20: Observation: Clear riffle-run-pool or step-pool sequence at expected spacing. Criteria: Robust bedform variety for stream type.
column23: Observation: Some diversity but units less distinct or irregular spacing. Criteria: Partially uniform bed with intermittent units.
column29: Observation: Mostly homogeneous bed; sequences faint or discontinuous. Criteria: Minimal expression of expected units.
column32: Observation: Flattened or artificially uniform bed. Criteria: No meaningful bedform sequence.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Supports aquatic habitats through streambed material and bedform dynamics. Enhances habitat complexity and streambank stability.
column11: Large wood abundance and the presence of key pieces support pools, bars, and habitat diversity; expectations vary by stream size and region.
column13: Walk a representative reach and rate wood abundance in broad bins; note key pieces/rootwads/jams; use aerial imagery for visible jams and compare to reference conditions.
column20: Observation: Abundant large wood with key pieces/rootwads or small jams. Criteria: Meets upper-range reference for density and variety.
column23: Observation: Moderate wood; some larger pieces but patchy. Criteria: Slightly below reference; habitat added but less consistent.
column29: Observation: Very little wood; mostly small/decayed pieces. Criteria: Few or no key pieces; limited hydraulic influence.
column32: Observation: Almost no large wood where expected. Criteria: No key pieces or jams; far below reference unless naturally low wood.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Supports aquatic habitats through streambed material and bedform dynamics. Enhances habitat complexity and streambank stability.
column11: Near-channel forest supplies future wood; most recruitment comes from within about 20-30 m of banks.
column13: Map width and continuity of mature trees within ~30 m of each bank using imagery and field checks; note canopy gaps and downed trees.
column20: Observation: Continuous >=30 m mature forest on both banks. Criteria: Strong recruitment potential within ~30 m corridor.
column23: Observation: 15-30 m forested buffer with gaps or one bank narrower. Criteria: Partial coverage; recruitment reduced.
column29: Observation: Narrow (<15 m) or patchy trees with frequent breaks. Criteria: Few large stems near channel.
column32: Observation: No meaningful near-channel forest where forest is natural. Criteria: Grass/crops/development to top of bank; minimal recruitment.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Supports aquatic habitats through streambed material and bedform dynamics. Enhances habitat complexity and streambank stability.
column11: Combines substrate size distribution, embeddedness, and consolidation or armoring to assess pore space and habitat quality.
column13: Use a Wolman pebble count when feasible; estimate embeddedness; note consolidation or armor with a grab test. If needed, use qualitative bins for dominant substrate and embeddedness.
column20: Observation: Gravel-cobble mix with low fines and open pore space. Criteria: <25% embeddedness; little/no crusting or armor.
column23: Observation: Slight fines or coarsening; moderate embeddedness. Criteria: Embeddedness about 25-50%; light crusting/armoring.
column29: Observation: Fines blanket bed or strong armor limits pore space. Criteria: Embeddedness about 50-75% or surface locked.
column32: Observation: Fine-dominated bed or heavily locked armor. Criteria: Embeddedness >75% or severe armoring; minimal pore space.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Shade, solar input, and groundwater keep temperature and light within natural ranges for stream metabolism and dissolved oxygen.
column11: Moderate growth matches local light regime, unless historically high/low (e.g., blackwater).
column13: Visual percent cover or periphyton biomass
column20: Observation: Thin periphyton film on stable cobbles. No mats. Criteria: Minimal algae. No nuisance mats.
column23: Observation: Light filaments on sunlit margins. Criteria: Slightly elevated algae coverage.
column29: Observation: Broad patches of filamentous algae covering riffles. Criteria: Large mats partially impair habitat.
column32: Observation: Thick blooms and scums that blanket the bed and trap fine sediment. Criteria: Dense bloom or scum overshadowing substrate.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Shade, solar input, and groundwater keep temperature and light within natural ranges for stream metabolism and dissolved oxygen.
column11: Shade is sufficient for this stream type, matching historical conditions unless naturally open.
column13: LiDAR or hemispherical photo shade percent
column20: Observation: Closed canopy of mature hardwoods and conifers. Continuous overchannel foliage. Criteria: 75-100% shade where forested reference conditions are expected.
column23: Observation: Mixed canopy with gaps near crossings and meadows. Criteria: 50-75% shade.
column29: Observation: Fragmented tree line with long open reaches beside pasture. Criteria: 25-50% shade.
column32: Observation: Cleared banks and open valley floor in a historically forested setting. Criteria: <25% shade. Note that excessive shade would be flagged only in historically open systems.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Shade, solar input, and groundwater keep temperature and light within natural ranges for stream metabolism and dissolved oxygen.
column11: Stays within acceptable bounds for local aquatic life, rarely exceeding stress thresholds.
column12:
Context: Field

Method: Use continuous or spot water-temperature records to assess maxima and diel range. Use modeled products where monitoring data are absent.
column13: Rarely surpasses local standard or typical seasonal maxima for the stream type.
column20: Observation: Logger record shows summer highs below local standard. Small diel range. Criteria: Rarely surpasses local standard. For screening, <20 C in coldwater or <28 C in warmwater.
column23: Observation: Occasional brief exceedances during heat waves. Criteria: Slightly exceeds threshold occasionally.
column29: Observation: Repeated warm afternoons near or over the threshold each week. Criteria: Frequent near or over threshold.
column32: Observation: Daily exceedance and several events approaching lethal levels. Criteria: Consistently high or lethal temperatures.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Shade, solar input, and groundwater keep temperature and light within natural ranges for stream metabolism and dissolved oxygen.
column11: Springs or deeper pools temper extremes, unless large daily swings are historically normal (arid ephemeral).
column13: Locate cooler pockets or deeper pools using a field temperature check or loggers where available.
column14: Field IR gun or loggers; mapped springs/seeps and baseflow indices (where available).
column20: Observation: Multiple cold seeps and deep pools evident. Fish aggregations present on hot days. Criteria: Multiple cooler pockets or deeper pools moderating temperature extremes.
column23: Observation: One small spring-fed side channel with limited extent. Criteria: One to two minor or limited refuges.
column29: Observation: Scattered weak cool spots with little depth refuge. Criteria: Rare or minimal cooler zones. Partial stress.
column32: Observation: No detectable cool pockets in a reach that historically had springs or deep pools. Criteria: No refuges where historically expected. High thermal risk.

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Organic matter is captured and broken down, fueling food webs, balancing production/ respiration, moderating pH/ redox, and supplying nutrients.
column11: Balanced algae/macrophyte growth, no nuisance blooms, unless moderate coverage is historically normal.
column13: Chl-a grab sample or algal percent
column20: Observation: Thin biofilm with visible gravel and cobble. No mats Criteria: Balanced growth and no nuisance bloom
column23: Observation: Slight periphyton increase. Occasional filament clusters Criteria: Slightly elevated algae
column29: Observation: Frequent moderate mats in glides and pools Criteria: Moderate nuisance mats that partially impair habitat
column32: Observation: Thick mats or scums widespread. Substrate obscured Criteria: Dense blooms overshadowing habitat

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Organic matter is captured and broken down, fueling food webs, balancing production/ respiration, moderating pH/ redox, and supplying nutrients.
column11: Leaf litter/coarse organic matter are visibly retained, supporting detrital processes per local references.
column13: Count leaf packs and small debris dams, or infer retention from wood presence and low-velocity habitat during a field visit.
column14: Field observation; wood and habitat assessments; planform complexity from imagery as supporting context.
column20: Observation: Stable leaf packs lodged behind wood and in low-velocity pockets along most of the reach Criteria: Abundant CPOM retention and multiple debris accumulations typical for forested systems
column23: Observation: Leaf packs present but many flush out after moderate storms Criteria: Some retention with partial flushing
column29: Observation: Only scattered leaves on bars or in eddies. Bed often scoured clean Criteria: Sparse organic matter and limited retention
column32: Observation: Bed largely bare with thin organic film or black, anoxic conditions Criteria: No effective retention or severe overload causing anoxia

column7: SFARI rapid scoring
column10: Organic matter is captured and broken down, fueling food webs, balancing production/ respiration, moderating pH/ redox, and supplying nutrients.
column11: Visible fungal colonization/shredding indicates a healthy detrital cycle.
column13: Leaf-pack decay bags (mass loss percent)
